left.text: RHAIL supported by AIM-AHEAD Program for AI Readiness (PAIR)
left.textSubsidiary: RHAIL, supported by the AIM-AHEAD Program for AI Readiness (PAIR), is at the forefront of integrating artificial intelligence into health research. Our lab focuses on developing AI-driven solutions that enhance diagnostic accuracy, optimize treatment protocols, and improve patient outcomes. Through PAIR, we leverage cutting-edge AI technologies and collaborate with industry leaders to prepare the next generation of researchers for the evolving demands of healthcare innovation.

one.text-1-3: A diverse team of leading experts drives our academic excellence

two.text-2-3: Our projects foster interdisciplinary knowledge and offer opportunities for mutual learning in the field of Resonsible Health AI

three.text-3-3: We collaborate with a vast array of partners across varied disciplines

regionThree.titleSecondary: Our lab is sponsored by PAIR award administered by AIM-AHEAD (NIH). Learn more about PAIR and how you can get involved!

body.content: I am interested in contacting you to learn more about your RHAIL.

FacultyList.name: Martine De Cock, Ph.D.
FacultyList.title: Professor
FacultyList.introduction: Dr. Martine De Cock is a Professor at the Institute of Technology, University of Washington Tacoma, and a guest professor at Ghent University. She holds M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees in Computer Science from Ghent University. Dr. De Cock has extensive experience in artificial intelligence, data mining, machine learning, and information retrieval, with over 150 peer-reviewed publications. She has served as a visiting scholar at the University of California, Berkeley, and Stanford University. Her current research focuses on secure machine learning, social networks, and data analytics to improve healthcare. She is an associate editor for IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems and has co-organized the KDDCup2013.

FacultyList.name: Weichao Yuwen, Ph.D.
FacultyList.title: Assistant Professor
FacultyList.introduction: Dr. Weichao Yuwen is an Assistant Professor at the University of Washington Tacoma. She conducts research in developing, testing, and disseminating technology-enabled health solutions for individuals with chronic conditions and their family caregivers. Dr. Yuwen is actively involved in the American Medical Informatics Association and the International Family Nursing Association and is a founding board member of the Pacific-Northwest Chinese Nurses Association. Her interdisciplinary research contributes to innovative digital health interventions that enhance patient care and support networks.

FacultyList.name: Ling-Hong Hung, Ph.D.
FacultyList.title: Research Assistant Professor
FacultyList.introduction: Dr. Ling-Hong Hung is a Research Assistant Professor at the University of Washington Tacoma with expertise in bioinformatics, big data, and machine learning. His research integrates computational methodologies to process and analyze large-scale biological data, contributing to advancements in genomics and biomedical informatics. Dr. Hung's work is instrumental in the development of efficient algorithms for data-driven insights in medical and biological sciences.

EventList.col3: We will present our work on 'Transforming Tuberculosis Care: Optimizing Large Language Models for Enhanced Clinician-Patient Communication' at the AAAI 2025 workshop on Generative AI for Health.
Daniil Filienko has been awarded a NIH AIM-AHEAD Research Fellowship, Cohort 3.
RHAIL is a NIH AIM-AHEAD PAIR Phase 2 awardee.

EventList.col1: Pilot Funding from UW Institute of Translational Health Sciences
EventList.col3: Our project on using generative AI to assist cultural and linguistic adaptations of clinical trial materials has been awarded pilot funding by the UW Institute of Translational Health Sciences.

EventList.col1: Accepted Paper at AMIA 2024 Annual Symposium
EventList.col3: Our paper on comparing prompting techniques to improve GPT-delivered Problem-Solving Therapy is accepted for presentation at the AMIA 2024 Annual Symposium.
Our poster on developing an AI-assisted platform to support tuberculosis care delivery is accepted for presentation at the 34th Medical Informatics Europe (MIE2024) conference.
RHAIL alumna Caroline El Jazmi was recognized in the Commencement speech of UWT Chancellor Lange.

EventList.col1: UW Population Health Initiative Pilot Grant
EventList.col3: RHAIL received a UW Population Health Initiative pilot research grant on 'Building and evaluating AI-augmented treatment support for individuals with tuberculosis' in collaboration with Biobehavioral Nursing and Health Informatics (UW Seattle).
RHAIL received a UW Tacoma Founders Endowment Grant for research on 'Privacy-Preserving Generative AI for Equitable Cancer Research'.

EventList.col1: Andrew and Julie Fry Innovation Award
EventList.col3: Daniil Filienko and Caroline El Jazmi received the Andrew and Julie Fry Innovation Award at the School of Engineering and Technology for their work on the 'Caring for Caregivers Online' (COCO) project.
Steven Golob has been selected for an AIM-AHEAD Traineeship in Advanced Data Analysis using the All of Us Clinical Database.
The RHAIL lab has been selected for the first NIH supported AIM-AHEAD PAIR cohort.
We received a UW Global Innovation Fund award in support of our research on 'Fair and Privacy-Preserving Machine Learning for Chronic Disease Symptom Management'.
